metadata.title: An overview of advanced methods for the characterization of oxygen vacancies in materials

sections.text:
lable at ScienceDirect
Contents lists avai
Trends in Analytical Chemistry
journal homepage: www.elsevier .com/locate/ t rac
An overview of advanced methods for the characterization of oxygen vacancies in materials
Kaihang Ye b, 1, Kunshan Li a, 1, Yirui Lu a, Zhongjie Guo a, Nan Ni b, Hong Liu a, Yongchao Huang a, *, Hongbing Ji b, ***, Pingshan Wang a, **
a Research Institute of Environmental Studies at Greater Bay, Key Laboratory for Water Quality and Conservation of the Pearl River Delta, Ministry of Education, Guangzhou University, Guangzhou 510006, China b Fine Chemical Industry Research Institute, School of Chemistry, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou 510275, Guangdong, China
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Available online 9 May 2019
Keywords: Oxygen vacancies Detection method Electron paramagnetic resonance Positron annihilation spectroscopy Surface defects
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. *** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: huangych@gzhu.edu.cn (Y. H (H. Ji), chemwps@csu.edu.cn (P. Wang).
1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.trac.2019.05.002 0165-9936/© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a b s t r a c t
Oxygen vacancy plays an important role in many fields, such as photocatalysis, energy storages, electrocatalysis, which has been widely investigated both by experiment and theoretical calculations. Herein, this review presents the new type and advanced methods to detect the existence of oxygen vacancies in nanomaterials, such as, electron paramagnetic resonance, synchrotron radiation-based X-ray absorption fine structure, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and positron annihilation spectroscopy measurements. In addition, we provide some perspectives on the challenge and new direction for future research in oxygen vacancy. We hope that this minireview can offer some useful contributions to the future development of defective nanomaterials for diverse application.
© 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Metal oxides have attracted considerable attention as catalytic materials for many applications, due to their natural abundance, excellent chemical stability, low cost and special electronic structures [1e9]. Many strategies have been studied deeply to develop the high-performance of metal oxides catalysts, such as heterojunction, doping, and supported noble metals [10e18]. Interestingly, recently a lot of reports revealed that defects in the metal oxide play a very important role in catalysis [19e23].
Oxygen vacancy (OVs) was first proposed in 1960 and used to study the gases in contact with a solid surface [24]. Until 2000, researchers found that surface oxygen vacancies could act as the reactive sites by scanning tunneling microscopy, where could absorb carbon monoxide and translate into carbon dioxide [25]. Later, Schaub et al. used high-resolution scanning tunneling microscopy to reveal the existence of oxygen vacancies on rutile TiO2 [26]. Lately, Dong reported that surface synergetic oxygen vacancy
uang), jihb@mail.sysu.edu.cn
played important to the heterogeneous catalytic reaction (CuO/ VOx/Ti0.5Sn0.5O2), such as NO reaction and CO reaction [27,28]. Therefore, oxygen vacancy is confirmed by theoretical calculation and experimental characterizations that it could be the most reactive site on the surfacematerials, modifying the structure of the materials, and changing the electronic and chemical properties of the surface [29e34]. In catalytic filed, oxygen vacancies play a substantial role in catalysis and following are the main points [7,35e40]: 1) Introducing additional energy levels in material. 2) Acting as specific reaction sites for some molecules in catalysis. It could acts as electron scavenger and then translate the attach oxygen gas to superoxide radicals. 3) Causing a change in chemical rates that depends on charge transfer from either electrons or holes. 4) Enhancing the electrical conductivity for materials.
Defects mainly include several types, anion vacancies (oxygen vacancies), cation vacancies, distortions and vacancy associates [39,41]. And engineering one of the defects could adjust the properties of materials, such as electronic structure, electrical conductivity property, and microstructure [7,42]. Furthermore, lots of methods are controlled to engineer formation of defects in nanomaterials, including thermal treatment in reducing gas or oxygen depleted condition, doping with other ions, structure of ultrathin materials (2D materials), and electrochemistry reduction and so on [11,43e47]. Most important of all, defects in materials had been confirmed that they have positive impact on materials. It
could be applied to a wide range of scientific research field (photocatalysis, electro-catalysis, thermal-catalysis, energy storages, and battery) and displayed its superiority (Fig. 1) [41,48e50].
Some works about oxygen vacancies have been summarize, which is focus on the synthetic approaches of materials with oxygen vacancies or the application of oxygen vacancies materials [8,34,51e53]. For examples, the achievement of 2D photocatalysts with defects has been summarized by Li's group [39]. They highlight the crucial roles of defects for photocatalysis. Furthermore, Wang et al. [41] summarized the development of oxygen defective materials for energy conversion and storage. Methods to create oxygen vacancies in catalysts and the applications of defective materials in energy conversion are their focus. Oxygen vacancies have been verified playing a vital role in catalysis, fuel cells and supercapacitors [54e56]. And the mechanism of oxygen vacancies in different application filed also has been studied systematically. However, the detecting instruments for studying oxygen vacancies have not keep up with the step, such as, quantifying and identifying the oxygen vacancies. Therefore, it is need to review the advanced characterization methods for oxygen vacancies research.
In this brief review, we summarize the present methods to detect the existence of oxygen vacancies in nanomaterials. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra and synchrotron radiationbased X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy are emphatically introduced, not cover all the detailed experimental means. Finally, we discuss the current challenges and opportunities about charactering oxygen vacancies in materials. It is hoped that this minireview can offer a useful technique to determine the action mechanism of oxygen vacancies during the reaction.

sections.heading: 2. The methods to detect the existence of oxygen vacancies
sections.text: Oxygen vacancies have been verified that they have positive effect on the catalysis. However, the roles of oxygen vacancies are still much debated [6,10,21,57]. To gain a fundamental understanding on the role of oxygen vacancies in materials, a versatile and powerful technique is very importance. Therefore, presenting the technologies of identifying oxygen vacancies is extremely urgent, which could study the relationship between the structure and properties of materials through the atomic level, opening the door to a new research field.

sections.heading: 2.1. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra
sections.text:
Electron paramagnetic spectroscopy is a straightforward and advanced technology to detect and characterize oxygen vacancies in nanomaterials [58]. It provides the finger printing information of unpaired electrons on both surface and bulk of the material; this is the signal of oxygen vacancies [59]. It is a very common means to
identify the single electron trapped and has considerable sensitivity [60]. What's more, the techniques could give the information regardless of the sample is liquid or solid.
EPR spectroscopy is based on the paramagnetic samples (with an unpaired electron) [61]. The samples could absorb electromagnetic radiation under a suitable magnetic field. That is to say, this phenomenon could occur at specific frequencies, depending on the following Eq. (1) [62]:
hv ¼ gbB (1)
where h is the Planck's constant, v is the frequency, g is a constant, ß is the Bohr magneton and B is applied magnetic field. Therefore, only the paramagnetic samples could absorb the resonances and no background affect from non-radical samples. The value of g is depended on the nature of radical. The g values of materials with oxygen vacancies are about 2.00, which is the diagnostic data for oxygen vacancies.
Until now, EPR is a common technique to identify the existence of oxygen vacancies in nanomaterials. For example, Zhang et al. [6,63] often used the EPR to estimate the oxygen vacancies concentrations of BiOCl samples, which indicated that the defects were mainly on the surface of those BiOCl samples. The black BiOCl with oxygen vacancies uniquely demonstrate a representative EPR signal at g ¼ 2.002, revealing the electron trapping at oxygen vacancies. Furthermore, Xiong et al. [52] characterized the defective WO3 (RWO3) nanosheets via EPR spectra, which is shown in Fig. 2. The g value of defectiveWO3 nanosheets is about 2.002, which is a typical example of oxygen vacancies. The existence of oxygen vacancies could trap the electron to absorb the resonances. The authors display the schematic illustrating the local structural information on defective WO3. We prepared defect rich-BiOX nanosheets via several methods, such as electroreduction, NaBH4 reduction, doping and ultrasound method [20,43e46,64,65]. And found that regardless of methods to obtain defect rich-BiOX samples, they all demonstrated EPR signals at g ¼ 2.00, which is the information of unpaired electrons, revealing the presence of oxygen vacancies. Therefore, EPR measurement is a direct and effective method to confirm the existence of oxygen vacancies in materials.
Although EPR technique could directly identify the existence of defects, it could not distinguish the types of defects, such as anion vacancies, cation vacancies, and pits. Furthermore, it also could not confirm that the defects are in the bulk or on the surface of materials. We believed that those problems will be resolved in the future with the efforts of scientists.
2.2. Synchrotron radiation-based X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy
XAFS has been widely used for many scientific fields, covering chemistry, environmental science, and materials, etc. It offers a power method to ascertain the electronic structures and the existence of oxygen vacancies [66,67]. XAFS could provide the structure information, such as oxidation states, bond length and types, atomic coordination number [68]. Therefore, it could be suitable to investigate defects, the atomic coordination number and more structure information in materials. Furthermore, qualitative defect level can be obtained by looking at the distance of the neighboring coordination atoms of migration and its peak intensity.
Recently, research article reported that using XAFS technology to research rich-defects CaMnO3 electrode materials [69]. The researchers used XAS and XANES mapping to analyze the oxygen vacancies in the materials. It can be seen that the peak intensity of CMO/S-300 is significantly lower than the peak intensity of CMO from XANES spectrum, proving that the valence states in materials
reduces after reduction of sulfur. Furthermore, the peak strength of CMO/S-300 in Fourier transforms decreases compared with CMO and some peaks corresponding to the spacing to drift. The data illustrates the surface structure changed and formed the oxygen vacancies in CMO/S-300. Xie Yi demonstrated XAFS measurement to validate Co defects confined on the surface of the CoSe2 ultrathin nanosheets, which is shown in Fig. 3. The Fourier transformed curve of bulk CoSe2 show the nearest CoeSe coordination with a main peak at 2.12 Å. However, the peak intensities of ultrathin CoSe2 nanosheets decreased and shifted to low R by 0.04 Å. The author attributed this to surface structural disorder of the ultrathin nanosheets, and the coordination missing accompanied by Co defects formation [70]. Furthermore, Yujie Xiong [52] also compared the WeO bonds lengths with bulk WO3 and deficient WO3. Specifically the reduction of coordination number mainly occurs at the longer WeO bonds of deficient WO3, identifying the locations of oxygen vacancies.

sections.heading: 2.3. Positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS)
sections.text:
Positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy (PALS) is a well versatile, unique and certain technique. It could directly measure the sub-nanometer sized molecular unoccupied volumes. A positron is injected into the material and then tested the length of time till it annihilated with one of electrons in materials producing gamma rays [71]. The lifetime of the positron is a measure of the local electron density at the point of annihilation. Positrons preferentially reacted in the low electron density regions (vacancy, microvoids). Therefore, it could be used to detect the defective types and the relative concentration of defects based on the positron lifetime. PALS has the following advantages: 1) Extremely sensitive to defects and microstructural changes at atomic scale; 2) No damage to the sample and finding defects actively; 3) Slow
positron technology has energy adjustable; depth analysis of defective or structurally inhomogeneous samples can be obtained.
The lifetime of the positron could be obtained by PATFIT program as following
N(t) ¼ PiIi/ti exp( t/ti) (2)
Xie's group used the positron annihilation lifetime spectroscopy to distinguish the different vacancy according to the positron annihilation lifetime [72]. VBi000VO VBi000 vacancy associates displays the positron lifetime for 325 ps, while the Bi vacancies shows 250 ps positron lifetime. The different lifetime provided the information on the vacancies distribution. VBi000VO VBi000 vacancy associates are preferentially presence in the ultrathin BiOCl, while Bi defects exist in BiOCl nanoplates. Furthermore, they also used PALS to detect the Bi-or Cu vacancy BiCuSeO samples [73]. Bi vacancy BiCuSeO has a 290 ps lifetime, while Cu vacancy BiCuSeO has a small lifetime (205 ps). Bi/Cu dual deficient in BiCuSeO sample displays more extra lifetime, revealing that Bi and Cu vacancies are predominant in the samples. Pan et al. [74] used PALS to characterize the oxygen vacancies with HeTiO2. They give the detailed explanation for positron lifetime spectrum from TiO2 and HeTiO2 and summarized that some larger size defect clusters and Ti3þwere detected in the HeTiO2 sample. Recently reported a palladium doped molybdenum disulfide materials research [75]. The defects after doping were characterized by using PALS technique, which is shown in Fig. 4. The researchers found that after MoS2 materials doped with 1% of the palladium, the relaxation time of lattice defects t1 and relaxation time of vacancy defects t2 significantly extended. The t1 changes from 183.6 ps to 206.2 ps, while t2 changes from 355.5 ps to 384.6 ps. The improvement of relaxation times reveals the defect dimension of ascension. In addition, the strength of the relaxation time is also improved, meaning that the
er transforms. Reprinted with permission from Ref. [70].
content of defects in material after doping is significantly higher than that of without doping MoS2.

sections.heading: 2.4. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS)
sections.text:
Defects will cause the atoms with low coordination numbers in the structure of materials, providing coordinative unsaturated sites for oxygen species chemisorption. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is one of the most widely used surface analysis methods [76,77]. It could be applied to most of the solid materials, providing chemical state and valuable quantitative information from the surface of materials. It can get the information from the surface about 10 nm depth [52,78]. Structure and principle of the instrument is covered in detail in many research summaries [78,79]. The defects in materials will change the bonding energies and this could be observed from the shifting peak or a new appeared peak. Therefore, XPS could be applied as an effectivemethod to detect the oxygen atoms or unsaturated sites involved in defective materials, comparing with the materials without defects.
Our group used a simple method to prepared BiOI with oxygen vacancies via a low-frequency ultrasound and found that the defect rich-BiOI (R-BiOI) nanosheets demonstrated superior photocatalytic performance [20]. The oxygen vacancies were affirmed by the O 1s XPS spectra of defect rich-BiOI, which is displayed in Fig. 5. The peaks at 529.5 eV can be indexed to the lattice oxygen and the peaks at 531.5 eV arise from the oxygen species chemisorbed at oxygen vacant sites, respectively. This also suggests that the oxygen vacancies are stabilized by the adsorbed oxygen species, a typical feature for the defect rich oxides. This phenomenon could be also seen in other deficient metal oxide (O 1s XPS), such as W18O49, CeO2-X, TiO2-X and defective ZnO [74,80e84]. Furthermore, carbon nitride with nitrogen vacancies was formed by post-treatment
method (hydrogen reduction). The authors used XPS valence band spectra to identify the presence of vacancies, valence band edge of vacancies C3N4 is higher 0.44 eV than that of C3N4 [85].

sections.heading: 2.5. Raman spectroscopy
sections.text:
Raman spectroscopy is an analytical tool for the study of molecular structure to get the information of molecular vibration and rotation [86]. Different chemical bonds has different vibration mode, determining the level of energy between changes [87]. The change of molecular vibrational level gives rise to the Raman shift. Therefore, Raman shift has some correlation with the lattice vibrational modes and it could be used to investigate the structure characteristics of materials. Defects in materials especially metal oxides can impact the vibrational modes, causing the Raman shift or appearing new peaks [88].
Our recent works demonstrated Raman spectroscopy to reveal the presence of oxygen vacancies in the structure of the Eu-doped CeO2 nanosheets [82]. Compared with the CeO2 nanosheets, a peak at 600 cm 1appeared for Eu-doped CeO2 nanosheets, suggesting that oxygen vacancies is generated due to the presence of Ce3þ and Eu3þ (Fig. 6). Furthermore, we engineered the defective bismuth oxyiodide by doping IO3 , which increased the performance of photocatalysis [45]. Bi vacancies could be observed in the defective BiOI samples via Raman spectra. A new peak appeared at 98 cm 1 is indexed to Bi vibration modes. It reveals that Bi valence states have changed due to the oxygen vacancies existence. It is interesting to note that Raman spectra technology had been applied to other metal oxides [89], such as defective Bi2WO6 [48], BiO2-x nanosheets [57], MnOx/CeO2 [12], which the down-shifts of Raman peaks and surface defects have some correlation.
printed with permission from Ref. [20].

sections.heading: 2.6. Scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM)
sections.text:
STEM has been used to characterize the structure of nanomaterials, which direct images the atomic structure [90]. The atomic numbers and the arrangement of each atom could be observed in the crystal structure by STEM, making it significant role on broad application in science research area, such as surface science, material science, life science [91]. However, this technique is only observed the local area on the surface of materials. It is too limit to study the overall defects in materials and it requires very thin samples for beam electrons to transmit.
In 2000, researchers found that surface oxygen vacancies could act as the reactive sites by scanning tunneling microscopy, where could absorb carbon monoxide and translate into carbon dioxide [25]. Later, Samuel S. Mao et al. [25] used STEM to study the atomicscale structure of RuO2 and found the defects in the materials surface (Fig. 7). The study by Hou et al. [84] revealed that bridgebonded defects in reduced TiO2 surface acted as the adsorption sites for carbon monoxide, which is confirmed by the STEM measurement.

sections.heading: 2.7. Density function theory (DFT) calculation
sections.text:
Density function theory (DFT) is computingmethod to study the electronic structure of materials. It is the quantum mechanical modeling to investigate the atoms, molecules [92]. Electron density could be proposed by using functional. Therefore, DFT is the versatile methods to be used in physics, computational chemistry and materials.
Zhao et al. [34] used DFT calculations to reveal the structure model of Vo-MnO2. Compared with the non-defective MnO2, VoMnO2's total and partial density of states are near the Fermi level, demonstrating that oxygen vacancies present in the materials. This phenomenon causes the enhanced electrical conductivity, electron transport properties. Importantly, the results of calculation are agree with the experimental results, suggesting that DFT could be used to auxiliary identify the existence of oxygen vacancies. Cheng et al. [93] combined experimental and calculation methods to understand the electronic structures of defects rich-TiO2 with different concentrations of oxygen vacancies. They demonstrated that two hydrogen atoms occupant in defects give rise to a new band in the bandgap of TiO2. And the different concentrations of oxygen vacancies cause different expanded energy, showing different absorption edge of TiO2. Although DFT calculation could propose the electronic structure of materials, it could only be used
as an auxiliary mean. Without doubt, combining experimental and calculation results could provide more effectively adequate data and evidence. Furthermore, it is still difficulties to use DFT to describe under the following situations: molecular interaction, the states of transition, excitations of charge transfer, and materials with ferromagnetism.

sections.heading: 2.8. Other methods
sections.text: Many other methods could also use to further identify existence of OVs due to the especial property of OVs, such as thermogravimetric analysis (TG). This method offers the information about physical phenomena, including absorption, decomposition. Oxygen vacancies could be refill with oxygen, especially in high temperature, suggesting that the mass of samples will change. This subtle mass change could be shown up in TG as the temperature increases. For example, bulk Bi2MoO6 sample demonstrated drastic weight loss, while ultrathin Bi2MoO6 nanosheets lost its weight gently under the oxygen gas atmosphere with the increased temperature [64]. This is due to the oxygen vacancies in ultrathin Bi2MoO6 nanosheets reacted with oxygen gas, mitigating the extent of its decline. Furthermore, temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) sometime also performed to characterize the surface property of solid materials. Compared with the bulk materials, defective materials significantly enhanced the extraction of surface lattice oxygen species [94,95].

sections.heading: 3. Summary and outlook
sections.text:
This minireview presents the new type methods to detect the existence of oxygen vacancies in nanomaterials, such as electron paramagnetic resonance, synchrotron radiation-based X-ray absorption fine structure, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and positron annihilation spectroscopy measurements. Such methods are very importance for us to understand the defects in materials. Although the oxygen vacancies are investigated both by theoretical calculations and experimental characterizations, the deep understanding of the role of oxygen vacancies in catalytic processes is still in an infant stage. It has been verified that the defective materials are advantageous for a wide range of application, such as, photocatalysis, electro-catalysis, thermal-catalysis, energy storages, and battery.
Although recent advancements achieved, the related research is still in the beginning stages. It is urgent to develop an effective and general method to identify the oxygen vacancies, especially, quantitative methods, advanced qualitative methods, distinguishing the type of vacancies and defects can be observed during the reaction process. Effective means have a great help for us to understand the role of oxygen vacancies. Hopefully, this minireview would stimulate further on going interest in the development and thorough characterizations of materials with defect sites, and advance their applications for solving the current and future challenges.

metadata.abstractText: Oxygen vacancy plays an important role in many fields, such as photocatalysis, energy storages, electrocatalysis, which has been widely investigated both by experiment and theoretical calculations. Herein, this review presents the new type and advanced methods to detect the existence of oxygen vacancies in nanomaterials, such as, electron paramagnetic resonance, synchrotron radiation-based X-ray absorption fine structure, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and positron annihilation spectroscopy measurements. In addition, we provide some perspectives on the challenge and new direction for future research in oxygen vacancy. We hope that this minireview can offer some useful contributions to the future development of defective nanomaterials for diverse application. © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
